Award.AwardTitle: Origins of Spin-Orbit Misalignments in Extrasolar Planetary Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The earliest searches for extrasolar planets uncovered an unexpected class of giant planets that orbit twenty times closer to their host stars than the Earth does to the Sun. Just how these planets came to orbit so close to their host star has become even more perplexing, as recent observations have shown that some of these planets orbit in direction that does not correspond with the star's spin, unlike planets in our solar system. The PI will conduct a comprehensive theoretical study of the key physical processes that act to sculpt planetary systems, including our own. This project will provide a strong basis for the training of a graduate student. The PI will also mentor high school students through Caltech's "summer research connection" program.

This theoretical/computational investigation will focus on reconciling smooth nebular-driven migration of giant planets and large spin-orbit misalignments through the disk-torquing mechanism. The effects of dynamical evolution within multiple star systems on the large-scale structure of the planet-forming disks will be examined, and the possibility of chaotic evolution of stellar spin axes will be quantified. The dependence of the misalignment amplitude on the specific modes of magnetic and gravitational disk-star coupling will be critically analyzed, with an eye towards explaining the observed correlation between orbital obliquity and stellar effective temperature.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The funded research program has led to the publication of 8 peer-reviewed manuscripts, numerous conference abstracts, and training of graduate, undergraduate, and high school students in a rapidly evolving STEM field. Cumulatively, the attained results present a new theoretical framework for the interpretation of observational data collected over the course of the last two decades. Hot Jupiters, which comprise the best-characterized sub-sample of extrasolar planets, are now understood to stem from the more prevalent population of lower-mass Super-Earth type planets that occupy the same orbital neighborhood (Batygin et al 2016; Bailey & Batygin 2018). Through analytical development and numerical simulations, we have demonstrated that observational work linking stellar mass to misalignments is fully consistent with predictions from the disk-torquing framework where in misalignments between stellar spin axes and planetary orbits are excited very early in the systems? evolution (Spalding & Batygin 2015, 2017; Spalding et al 2016).  This finding places the Sun?s small, but nevertheless non-negligible obliquity into the greater, extrasolar context. 

The work conducted under the funded research program has also yielded considerable insights into the dynamical evolution of systems of sub-Jovian planets. The Kepler mission and its successor K2 have shown that although a considerable fraction of detected planetary systems exhibit multiple members, a large portion possess only a single transiting example. The work performed by our group under support from NSF has demonstrated that this dichotomy is a natural consequence of planet-star interactions that unfold during the infancy of planetary systems, and arises inescapably if stellar spin-orbit misalignments are excited early, as envisioned within the framework of the disk-torquing mechanism (Spalding & Batygin 2016, Spalding et al 2018). In addition, by characterizing the intricate dynamical structure of select planetary systems (Batygin & Adams 2017), we have obtained estimates of specific tidal dissipation functions of an extrasolar Super-Earth (Puranam & Batygin 2018). Given that the physical nature of tidal dissipation remains imperfectly understood, these constraints provide a valuable window into the operation of the tidal heating mechanism in planetary objects completely unlike those that populate the solar system.
